title: Islamic State Targets New York City and Police With Online Propaganda
text:
Islamic State has ramped up threats against New York City and New York Police Department officers in recent weeks, counterterrorism officials said in interviews.

The overseas terrorist organization has been targeting New York City with a new flood of online propaganda that shows bloody images of police and digitally-faked threatening messages in subways, the officials said in interviews.

The rise in violent messages, which officials say are circulated online and intended to inspire and instruct potential terrorists, has persisted since it was first detected in July. Officials said the increase doesn’t represent an immediate threat to public safety and isn’t linked to Wednesday’s 18th anniversary of the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

“What we’ve seen lately, is an unusual amount of propaganda directed at attacks on U.S. soil and an unusual amount of that pointing to New York as a target,” said John Miller, NYPD Deputy Commissioner of Intelligence and Counterterrorism.

Islamic State rose to power more than a decade ago amid instability in Iraq. The group controlled a self-proclaimed caliphate in Iraq and Syria that was the size of Portugal at its peak, but collapsed this year after U.S.-backed Syrian forces defeated the last of its territories.

Mr. Miller said Islamic State’s loss of geographical territory and manpower has led to a rise of propaganda. Photo: Gabby Jones for The Wall Street Journal

Mr. Miller said that the terrorist organization’s loss of geographical territory and manpower has led to an increase in propaganda produced by a small number of remaining fighters.

“It is down to a very few people on a very small patch of real estate and it is trying to survive as an organization and as a voice,” Mr. Miller said.

The group has lost the ability to execute complex, coordinated attacks with imported fighters such as the three-coordinated strikes on Paris in 2015 in which 130 people were killed, Mr. Miller said. But it has shifted its emphasis to reaching local extremists with propaganda meant to inspire individual attacks, the deputy commissioner said.

“They haven’t lost the technical ability to create new material, fresh propaganda and increase the volume on their calls for lone wolves to attack,” Mr. Miller said. “If one or two of these people decide to act on it, for ISIS, that is a win,” he said, using an acronym for the group.

Rita Katz, the director of SITE Intelligence Group, which monitors and tracks radical groups online, said New York City remains a top target for terrorists because it “embodies American culture, making it a highly symbolic location.”

“Most propaganda featuring New York City isn’t only a threat to the city itself, but also anywhere and everywhere in America,” she said.

The last three Islamic terror attacks in New York City were executed by extremists motivated by such messaging, Mr. Miller said. That list includes Ahmad Khan Rahimi, who was convicted of detonating a bomb on a Manhattan sidewalk in 2016; Akayed Ullah, who was convicted of detonating a bomb in a Manhattan subway station in 2017; and Sayfullo Saipov, who is accused of using a truck to crush people on a bike path in lower Manhattan in 2017.

More recent arrests of individuals who are accused of planning attacks, including Ashiqul Alam, who allegedly planned an attack in Manhattan’s Times Square, may also have been informed by Islamic State propaganda, Mr. Miller said.

The NYPD operates the largest counterterrorism apparatus of any law enforcement agency in the U.S., with hundreds of staff officers and analysts and extensive relationships with outside intelligence agencies.

Analysts in the NYPD’s intelligence and counterterrorism units have encountered a growing number of messages encouraging attacks on soft targets such as the Thanksgiving Day Parade, holiday markets and public transit systems, including the subway, officials said.

Likewise, analysts have discovered more propaganda that encourages violence against police. On Aug. 23, NYPD officials alerted precinct commanders and officers to two such messages with a tactical bulletin.

The bulletin said that two posters targeting NYPD were reported on a pro-Islamic State channel on the Telegram messaging app on Aug. 19, both of which displayed a blood drip-style font reading “Pigs! You will Soon Pay For Your Crimes.”

One of the posters showed an image of an active NYPD officer. The officer was unharmed and was unaware the image had been used, officials said.

NYPD Chief of Counterterrorism James Waters said the tactical assessment was delivered to officers to increase vigilance and to prompt conversation about terrorist threats in general.

“It gave us yet another good opportunity to reach out to all the cops, review tactics and personal safety and give them awareness,” Chief Waters said.
